qas.question: When, during the partitions of Poland, did the szlachta lose legal and social status.
What was one name of a power that the szlachta was dependent on.
When was the March constitution implemented.
What did the Mach constitution do?

answers.text: legal privileges of the szlachta were legally abolished

qas.question: In what republic did the szlachta lose their legal privileges.

context: During the Partitions of Poland from <a0_0>1772 to 1795<a0_0/>, its members began to lose these legal privileges and social status. From that point until 1918, the legal status of the nobility was essentially dependent upon the policies of the three partitioning powers: the <a1_0>Russian Empire<a1_0/>, the Kingdom of Prussia, and the Habsburg Monarchy. The <a3_0>legal privileges of the szlachta were legally abolished<a3_0/> in the <a4_0>Second Polish Republic<a4_0/> by the March Constitution of <a2_0>1921<a2_0/>.
